title: There are some axioms that have been proven to be independent of an axiom system. Are there axioms who's proof of independence is independent of that axiom system? - Quora

response.answer_text: Axiom independence From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia An axiom P is independent if there are no other axioms Q such that Q implies P.In many cases independence is desired, either to reach the conclusion of a reduced set of axioms, or to be able to replace an independent axiom to create a more concise system (for example, the parallel postulate is independent of other axioms of Euclidean geometry, and provides interesting results when a negated or replaced). Proving Independence If the original axioms Q are not consistent, then no new axiom is independent. If they are consistent, then P can be shown independent of them if adding P to them, or adding the negation of P, both yield consistent sets of axioms. For example, Euclid's axioms including the parallel postulate yield Euclidean geometry, and with the parallel postulate negated, yields non-Euclidean geometry. For examples, elliptic geometry (no parallels) and hyperbolic geometry (many parallels). Both elliptic and hyperbolic geometry are consistent systems, showing that the parallel postulate is independent of the other axioms. Proving independence is often very difficult. Forcing is one commonly used technique. Hope this helped you.

No. This would be a lot clearer if you talked about axioms and theorems, rather than axioms alone. Lets take a well known example, the Axiom of Choice. This cannot be proved (or disproved) in ZF. But it can certainly be proved true in ZFC, as it is in fact an axiom of this system. A theorem can be independent of some set of axioms. But it cannot be possibly be proved to be independent in all axiom systems, as you can simply add it as an axiom, and it automatically becomes provably true in that enlarged system - because it is an axiom of that system.
